[{'id': 462, 'article_title': 'West Coast of Africa', 'full_section_title': 'West Coast of Africa', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_11_1864#article-1', 'issue_date': '23_11_1864', 'content': "The African Mail steamer Calabar arrived at Liverpool Nov. 11. Her dates were: Benin, Sept. 14; Fernando Po, Sept. 29; Cameroons, Oct. 1; Old Calabar, Oct. 3; Brass River, Oct. 5; Bonny, Oct. 7; Lagos, Oct. 10; Accra, Oct. 12; Cape Coast Castle, Oct. 14; Cape Palmas, Oct. 16; Sierra Leone, Oct. 21; Bathurst, Oct. 25; Teneriffe, Oct. 30; Madeira, Nov. 2.

The Calabar brought 72 passengers, and 2,900 ounces of gold dust.

Commodore Wilmot, in the Rattlesnake man-of-war, had visited Benin in the early part of September, in order to enforce payment of the fine imposed by Governor Freeman at Lagos, in the early part of last year. The natives at Benin refused to pay. Commodore Wilmot at once stopped the trade of the river until the original fine, together with an addition of a large quantity of palm oil, should be paid. The Commodore, it was understood, would return again in December, and if the fine was not then paid, he would resort to measures rather disagreeable to the natives. The natives are, however, determined to resist what they consider an unjust demand.

A naval court had been held at Benin, by Commodore Wilmot, to inquire into the conduct of Captain Richardson, master of the ship Eagle's Wing. The charges being proved, he was deprived of the command of his vessel. An extraordinary freak by a shipmaster occurred on the 22nd September. The barque Irene, belonging to Messrs. Stuart and Douglas, of Liverpool, and loading at Benin, suddenly, and without any orders from the supercargo, got under weigh, and up to September 24th had not been heard of. The river healthy.

Trade very dull at Fernando Po. The island was healthy. Mr. J. W. Lynslager, formerly British Consul at Fernando Po, and for some time Spanish Governor at that port, died on the 15th September. He was well known for his generous hospitality, and was most sincerely esteemed both by the native and European population.

Trade dull at the Cameroons, in consequence of the disagreement among the natives. The river healthy.

Bonny, healthy and trade very brisk.

Trade entirely stopped at Brass, owing to a war between the Brassmen and a neighbouring tribe. The steamer Investigator had arrived from the Niger, with Dr. Baikie.

At Accra, business very dull. Small-pox was raging with fearful intensity when the mail left, and many deaths had occurred. Great dissatisfaction was felt at the conduct of the Cape Coast Government, in consequence of the non-appointment of a surgeon to assist, in the present state of the place.

Mrs. Blackall, the wife of the Governor of Sierra Leone, died on the 1st of October, after a very short illness."}, {'id': 540, 'article_title': 'General Observations', 'full_section_title': 'General Observations', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_02_1865#article-9', 'issue_date': '23_02_1865', 'content': '**GENERAL OBSERVATIONS.**

**SMALL-POX AT ACCRA.**—The deaths from small-pox at Accra, Gold Coast, in the Dutch and English towns, have been about 2,300 during the last four months of 1864, out of a population of from 8,000 to 9,000 only. About 6,000 are supposed to have suffered from the infection. Of 1,200 who were vaccinated by Doctor Gunn, S.A.S., many had the small-pox, but only twelve died.

**LAGOS.**—It is believed that Mr. Freeman will again go out from England and resume the government of this colony.

**LIBERIA.**—There are troubles with the natives on the seacoast, who oppose the new Government regulation which insists on all produce going to one or other of six ports for export.

**THE SIERRA LEONE EXHIBITION** is still fixed to open on the 28th February.

**PORTO NOVO.**—The French Government has entirely given up the protectorate of this place, which is so situate that they could not send a steamboat in without obtaining British permission for her passage through British waters.

**GAMBIA.**—By express desire, we insert a report on "Dykes and Drains" in the Island of St. Mary's, presented to the Executive Council by Governor D'Arcy.

**THE SLAVER CICERON.**—It is understood that during the absence of some of the blockading squadron from the coast of Dahomey, the above-named vessel slipped in near Porto Novo, embarked 1,500 slaves, and got safely off with them—bound for Cuba, of course.

**COTTON.**—Shipments of the new cotton from Accra, the produce of the Volta and Trans-Volta districts, are now being made by every mail steamer. It is expected that the quantity to be shipped from Accra this year will reach fifty or sixty tons—all brought down to the coast on human heads.'}, {'id': 2146, 'article_title': 'SMALL-POX AT CAPE PALMAS.', 'full_section_title': 'SMALL-POX AT CAPE PALMAS.', 'last_edit_date': '12-20-1871', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_02_1872#article-6', 'issue_date': '23_02_1872', 'content': 'The mail steamer brought the following sad news from Cape Palmas—viz., that the "small-pox" is fearfully raging in that county, and that numbers are dying from the disease. The only doctor in that county is a Dr. Fletcher. Though the "small-pox" is so fearful among the people, yet there is no vaccination. The people are dreadfully afraid of the disease; some of the young men went on board the mail-steamer and begged the doctor of the steamer to vaccinate them. The majority of the people do not know what vaccination is, and the effect it produces, consequently they have no faith in it, and will not go to their doctor to be vaccinated. The doctor of the steamer was informed of this. Dr. Fletcher says it is not only "small-pox," but it is both "small-pox" and "black measles;" some of the people have the "small-pox," and others the "black measles." The people told their doctor to his face that he was a liar, that it was not "black measles," but "small-pox." They will not listen to his advice, not to drink cold water, but they would drink, saying that he knew nothing about the disease. The people at last so tried their doctor's patience, and vexed him so sore, that he advised them to drink as much rum as they liked; so that drunkenness prevails to a fearful extent in the county, the people believing it will prevent them having the disease. The dead have no one to bury them, and none will follow their loved ones to the grave. It is also said the few who had it and recovered try to give it to those who have not had it, saying, that all should have it as they had. One Mr. R. S. M'Gill, a merchant in that county, built a "small-pox" house, and directed the Government to send to it all who have the disease; but very few went, and there was no power to compel the rest to go. This Mr. R. S. M'Gill, who is said to have been, and is still the main support of that county, and one or two others, have made provisions such as the county could afford for those who went to the "small-pox" house. Many of them might have recovered, but died from mere starvation. The mortality is fearful; the number of deaths is not ascertained. It is said that this is the first time the "small-pox" ever visited the Liberians at Cape Palmas, though they have had it always amongst the natives; but it never reached them in the
**[Feb. 28, 1873.]**

county till this time. There is no medicine whatever in that county to administer to the sick, not even common castor-oil could be got.'}, {'id': 2714, 'article_title': 'West Coast News', 'full_section_title': 'West Coast News', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/30_04_1874#article-1', 'issue_date': '30_04_1874', 'content': "The British and African Steam Navigation Company's mail steamer Bonny arrived in the Mersey on April 3, with dates from Cape Coast Castle to March 13. The news brought by the Bonny is to the effect that trade was stopped at the Cameroons in consequence of the fighting between the two kings. But the English Consul had arranged a truce to last during the three months of the oil season. Bonny and the other Oil Rivers were healthy.

Her Majesty's ship Decoy disembarked the Houssas at Lagos on the 3rd March, and took on board a company of the 2nd West India Regiment for Cape Coast. The natives of Jellah Coffee were still very restless. Small-pox had again broken out among the natives at Cape Coast Castle and Accra. The day before the Bonny left the former place an embassy from King Coffee arrived, but the object of the visit could not properly be ascertained before the vessel left."}, {'id': 3623, 'article_title': 'An Excessive Sentence at Lagos, Contrasting Strongly with That on Shankling', 'full_section_title': 'An Excessive Sentence at Lagos, Contrasting Strongly with That on Shankling', 'last_edit_date': '04-10-1878', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_08_1878#article-12', 'issue_date': '01_08_1878', 'content': 'Sir,—I now take up my pen with a view to express my entire sympathy with, and Christian affection towards, my coloured brother who of late has been unjustly imprisoned for ten years' penal servitude. I feel that I am laid under obligation by our

Christianity to "Remember them that are in bonds, as bond with them"; and they that suffer adversity, as though we suffer it ourselves. If I understand the injunction aright, I ought to feel for my fellow-creature under persecutions which he endured in consequence of circumstances over which he has no control, as though I were exposed to the like indignities.

At the Sessions held on the 8th of January last, a case of Abudukadiri, who was indicted for that, on the 1st day of December, 1877, he feloniously did kill a small-poxed Krooboy named Sampson, in his mother's yard, at the dead of night, was tried before the Honourable Judge Woodcock. I was present in court at the hearing of the case.

The prisoner pleaded not guilty. There were four witnesses—A Krooboy and Dr. McCarthy for the Crown, and Bamkole and James Daniel for the prisoner. The first witness (Krooboy) stated that the prisoner gave the deceased a blow of cutlass one time on his head, and that he had light before he did it; and that he was the man who carried the deceased away; and that the deceased died at 5 A.M. next morning.

This evidence, if believed, is enough to justify a sentence of twenty years' penal servitude; but the evidence of the learned Doctor, which comes immediately after, ought to have destroyed the thought of vengeance which has been reserved for the poor ignorant prisoner in any one's mind. He stated that the deceased received the wound on his left ear: and that in probing the same, he found that it was only "half-an-inch long," which goes to prove that the prisoner had no cutlass, but a stick; and also shows that the first witness was not an eye-witness when the deceased received the blow, which consequently makes him a false witness. He further stated that it is his firm belief and opinion that the blow in itself was not enough to account for death, and that the deceased died from the epidemic disease he had then upon him.

Bamkole stated that the prisoner had no cutlass, but a stick, and that he had knocked the deceased before light was brought in by a neighbour; and also that the deceased walked on his feet back to his yard, and was not carried by the first witness.'}]
tat_extra:
[{'document_title': 'SMALLPOX AT CAPE COAST.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'WE deplore, though we are not surprised, that the loathsome epidemic, smallpox, is committing its ravages at Cape Coast. The filthy condition of that town, fully exposed in late numbers of this journal, must without doubt tend to the increase of its severity, as well as to the number of attacks. A few years since (six, we believe), after great ravages of smallpox at Accra, when Dr. Gunn, who was at that time on the station, vaccinated a very considerable number of the native population, and thus, it was considered, did much to arrest the onward progress of the fatal disorder, we more than once called attention to the subject, in the hope that the British authorities in the settlements of this country on the Coast, would take some effectual measures for bringing the population gradually under that degree of protection which vaccination undoubtedly affords. We do not say what that degree is; but, looking at the European population in the present day, with their smooth, unmarked faces, we find they present so marked a contrast to those of the generation passed away, as to establish beyond dispute that the degree is a very considerable one. It is, therefore, greatly to be regretted that our self-martyrising, zealous Administrators on the West Coast, while "wearing themselves to the very verge of the grave" in their arduous exertions for the good of the native population, have not paid more attention to this important matter of the employment of preventive means for arresting the spread of that terrible scourge of Africa—smallpox—among the native people. In another column we publish a short account of an experience in this matter in the East Indies, where the prejudice against, or rather disbelief in the benefit of vaccination, has far exceeded anything of the kind experienced in Africa. Indeed, Dr. Gunn assured us at the time of the Accra outbreak, the people came willingly and with strong expressions of gratitude to obtain the protection (then proved in their eyes to be real) which vaccination affords. Whether the self-made Martyr Administrator of Cape Coast returns there, or some other aspirant martyr be sent out, we beg once again to express the hope that, by the formation of a vaccine institution, or by giving a fee per head to the Army and Colonial Surgeons for every child or adult properly and effectively vaccinated by them, or by some other active and dependable means, the native population in the future may be less exposed to the ravages of smallpox than it has been in the past. The records of travellers and explorers establish incontestably that smallpox is the great fatal disease of Africa. Among the great and precious benefits which European civilisation bestows on Africa, let this be one, that we make the results of our own experience instrumental in saving African lives from that fell destroyer. The propagation of vaccination ought to be actively carried on from every British settlement.', 'last_edit_date': '1871-09-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_09_1871#article-17', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.771, 'probability_score': 0.07, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Introduction of Present Epidemic of Small-pox into Cape Coast', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Dear Sir,—That dreadful disease the small-pox is raging fearfully here, and friends dear and precious in our eyes, and who might otherwise have been our joy for many long years to come, have been swept away by it. It becomes, then, our duty to hold up to public and superior official censure those in authority here who allowed such a disease to get into our colonial hospital, without taking proper precautions for the safety of other patients there, and of all the other inhabitants of this place. Many of us are mourning the death of our dearest friends through the gross and culpable neglect of our rulers. The fatal disease was brought here by a prisoner from Accra, landed here in May last from the steamship Biafra. Allow me, then, to ask the Colonial Surgeon, through your columns, whether it is his duty to receive patients into the hospital without knowing under what diseases they are suffering; whether he was aware that this prisoner was afflicted with small-pox, and admitted him into the hospital without those precautions for the safety of others that ought to have been taken, whereby hundreds are dying of the infection introduced by that prisoner from Accra. I say that he is responsible for the lives of those who are thus hurried into untimely graves; and I earnestly beg of you to expose this fatal negligence of those in authority. At the present time those who suffer under the disease are quartered in the centre of the town; hence people inhaling the poisonous odour are infected, and coffins are passing with dead bodies every day.', 'last_edit_date': '1871-08-29', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_10_1871#article-4', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.741, 'probability_score': 0.068, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'DIFFICULTIES IN VACCINATING', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Extract from a private letter, dated Winnebah, 25th January.

"I had a rather serious disturbance at 'Appam' on the 18th. I had four policemen, as some of the people had been opposed to vaccination and prevented others from coming to me. With these men I commenced vaccinating in the public highways and lanes in the centre of the town, and also visited each house. After vaccinating a great many persons, a Fetishman was brought to me, and I vaccinated him. One of my men attempted to bring a man who was near a gang of 100 canoe-men in a very narrow lane; he was set upon, and roughly handled by them. My attention was drawn to the spot, and I went and stopped them. We were at the centre of that part of the town (Fish-town) which is remarkable for its narrow lanes and wild inhabitants. The mob had increased to nearly 300, who, by their frantic gestures, showed us that we were in danger. I manœuvred cautiously out of the lanes, followed by them yelling, howling, and abusing me and my men, to an open space near a native factory, a ground-floor house built of mud. Here the number increased to above 500, infuriated by ardent spirits, and they threw sticks, stones, hardened bricks, and cocoanut-shells at us. The people from the huts in our rear began to join the others, and I withdrew the constables into the hut. They surrounded it, threw stones into it, hammered at the window, and called out loudly for my blood. I went out twice to try and appease them, but they showered stones at me. After going on in this way for nearly two hours—several times endeavouring to break into the place—they were dispersed by some of the elders. I left the town the same evening. It is arduous and dangerous work, but has been the means of saving a great many lives, and I am content.', 'last_edit_date': '1872-01-25', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_03_1872#article-6', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.693, 'probability_score': 0.065, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Gold Coast Must Be Kept Under British Influence', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Sir,—As you have already heard, the smallpox has been doing much havoc in James Town and Dutch Accra, but not so much at Christiansborg, probably because this place is more widely spread than the other two, which have clusters of houses on a small space. The other places to leeward—i.e., Labaday and Teshi—send their people (sick of the smallpox) out to the field, and stop all communication with the infected places, which is certainly a very good plan. The smallpox came down from Aquamu to the coast. The mountain district has been safe until lately, and Late only is infected. Of course, these people are very much afraid of this sickness, and ask advice of their priests, &c. Thus a Mohammedan doctor, or, as others say, a fetish priest, gave the clever advice that all red goats and red cocks should be killed, because the latter call the sickness by crowing, and the former impart the sickness to men. So the poor dupes set about killing them everywhere, and red goats and red fowls became very cheap! But the missionaries and Christians could not, of course, comply. They vaccinated their people, and kept goats and fowls alive. The rage of the heathen was, therefore, turned upon them. They caught the goats and killed them. The young men came to the mission premises and took what they could, white, black, or any other coloured beasts and fowls. In Aburi they assembled in the street, and with war songs marched to the Christian village to plunder. They could scarcely be persuaded to return. The Chief of Aburi refused to punish those who stole goats. They moreover forbade the use of the water well to all Christians. The Chief of Aquapem, Kwao Dade, forbade the women to cook for our boarding scholars, and the missionaries were obliged to send their stock away to avoid plundering.', 'last_edit_date': '1864-11-10', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_12_1864#article-17', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.695, 'probability_score': 0.065, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'SMALL-POX AT CAPE COAST.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'It seems that this malignant disease which carried off so many victims last year in the towns and villages of the Coast, is still far from having disappeared in the neighbourhood of Cape Coast Castle. It will be remembered that the local government very praiseworthily dispatched Dr. Horton in the direction of Appam, Mumford, and other places, to render assistance to the natives under the sad calamity; and that he vaccinated some thousands of them, notwithstanding the opposition of the Fetish priests. Dr. Horton received the thanks of the Right Hon. the Secretary of State for the Colonies, for the self-devotion and courage of which he gave proof on that occasion; and we are surprised that after such high official approval of the measures then adopted, the British local authorities have not, by some means or other, carried out a general system of vaccination of the entire population of Cape Coast Town, among whom the Acting Administrator, chief magistrate, and all the civil officials reside. The small-pox is a deadly disease in every part of the world to which it makes its visit, but has always been especially fatal among intertropical populations. It has been a greater depopulator of West Africa than any other disease known along the West Coast; and we hope that wherever the British authorities possess influence, that influence will be earnestly exerted in inducing the natives to be vaccinated. Vaccination is one of the real blessings of civilization; and we think it is the duty of the British authorities on the West Coast to do all in their power to induce the people to accept the protection which it undoubtedly offers.', 'last_edit_date': '1872-10-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_10_1872#article-17', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.722, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'SMALLPOX IN THE SEA-COAST TOWNS NEAR CAPE COAST.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Dear Sir,—I left Cape-coast under orders a fortnight or more ago because of the ravages of small-pox in these parts, that I might do all in my power to arrest and mitigate it by vaccination and medical treatment. I have now fairly commenced my series of vaccinations, and have succeeded so far in breaking through the prejudices of the people, that I hope to be able to vaccinate two-thirds of the population. I have already done the head-chief, captain, and principal inhabitants of the place. The people had made a sort of encampment or hospital on the beach, on the high road to Accra, Winnebah, and were actually exposing themselves to the people who passed by, so as to spread the disease as much as possible. We selected a hilly place, a mile from the town to leeward, and built there an encampment, huts, &c., and ordered them to remove to them, but they refused. On the 23rd December we burnt down the beach huts, and the patients were taken to the hill encampment. On the morning of the 25th we were informed that most of the patients had returned to the town, and we (Major Bromwell and myself) were engaged the whole of the day in visiting every suspected hut in the town and removing the patients. From some of the miserable huts we succeeded in getting out persons in the very worst stages of small-pox—some putrid from head to foot. The stench was fearful, but it had to be done, and we did it. I met with men, women, and especially children, who were unprotected; living with and even crawling about the sick. These are now suffering, and we have fresh cases every day. The Government is doing its best, and I am doing my utmost to mitigate the evil. On the 8th I think I leave this for Appam. I have already commenced vaccinating there. I have worked hard ever since my arrival, and have greatly ameliorated the condition of the suffering sick. A good many have returned to the town cured. This morning and noon I have vaccinated 260 persons. It will take me a long time to finish the other towns, but I hope to do great good in them.—Yours, truly,', 'last_edit_date': '1872-01-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_02_1872#article-7', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.726, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'West Coast of Africa', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The African Royal Mail steamer Africa, which arrived at Liverpool on 6th February, reports that trade on the Coast was dull, but health, though the weather was remarkably hot, fairly good. Small-pox prevailed in the interior of Accra District, and many of the natives had, it was reported, succumbed to the disease. The malady had also made its appearance at Krootown. At Quittah no further disturbances had taken place since the affair in which Commodore Ellis shot one of the natives of an adjacent town. The natives seemed anxious to have the matter investigated, and were eagerly waiting the arrival of Governor Freeling for that purpose.', 'last_edit_date': '1879-03-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_03_1879#article-2', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.703, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Vaccination', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The neglect of vaccination in our colonies has been remarked upon in late medical reports, and in the opening discourses of the lectures in the great London medical schools. In one of the latter it is stated: "This neglect is seen from the occurrence of small-pox among our troops stationed in various parts of Her Majesty's dominions. It appears from an elaborate paper on the results of re-vaccination in the British army, as compared with Continental armies, lately read before the Epidemiological Society, that no portion of the empire is exempt from the scourge. From Canada to the Mediterranean, from the West Indies to Sierra Leone, and from the Cape of Good Hope to India and China, the same tale is to be heard of small-pox prevalent among the civil populations, and of more or less disease among the troops in consequence.', 'last_edit_date': '1865-01-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_01_1865#article-10', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.721, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Small-pox in the Cape Coast Districts', 'section_title': '', 'content': "Sir,—In reading the issue of the African Times of July 24, I find Her Majesty's Government have duly approved of the services rendered by our excellent friend, Dr. Horton, during the outbreak of small-pox in this part of the Coast.

Dr. Horton was sent down here at the earliest part of the year to succeed Major Brownell, the Civil Commandant of Anamaboe, who had already been sent to see that those already affected with the disease were removed far from the town, to prevent others from being infected with, or taking, the disease; and Dr. Horton vaccinated a great many people in this and the neighbouring places, but many of whom manifested a great deal of opposition, but as a gentleman, he exercised a good deal of patience, and also a little force when necessary.

At Appam, Dr. Horton was, on one occasion, actually pelted with stones, and bringing the matter before the Justice of the Peace at this place, they (the Appam people) arranged their case quietly, and allowed themselves to be freely vaccinated, and that settled all the dispute.

I would write a great deal more of the troubles with which he met in this district, in the discharge of his duty, but it would, I fear, go against ourselves as natives wanting civilization. Suffice it to say that we are glad to find his labours, in the capacity of vaccinator, have not been coniired at by our most gracious Sovereign Lady, Queen Victoria. This is, at least, con-

sidered by some of us as an encouragement worthy of observation. The small-pox is still with us, and is committing its usual ravages; but it has, I must observe, nothing to do with the Hortonians, so to express myself. Those who at first refused to be vaccinated by this agreeable doctor, are the parties who are invariably affected with the disease. But almost all of them have now come to their right sense, and, in continuation of the scheme of Dr. Horton, they permit their arms to be freely vaccinated without fee. Mr. Josiah Bentill, of this town, has vaccinated a number of them, all gratis, and would have continued to vaccinate a great many more still, if he had not been out of arms ready with the vaccine lymph. Having arms ready with the virus, or the vaccine lymph, I vaccinated, at Tantum and Lagoe, in about fifteen days, more than 400 or 500 persons— men, women, and children.

You will, I trust, insert and publish this, if you think it worth doing so.—Believe me to be, yours obediently,", 'last_edit_date': '1872-08-26', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_10_1872#article-7', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.728, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Menace of War by Ashanti', 'section_title': '', 'content': "That virulent small-pox should be carrying off daily its ten or a dozen victims from among the small native population of Bathurst, or that any other fatal epidemic should be committing its ravages there, ought not to be a matter of surprise with any one who had read the accounts we have given from time to time, and very recently with added emphasis, of the infamous absence of all adequate sanitary regulations for making the place a safe habitation for human beings, whether white or black. We have, as our readers well know, felt the most serious apprehensions that the yellow fever, which had visited Senegal, would descend to Bathurst, as offering a most tempting field for it to revel in. Happily, however, according to latest advices, it seems to have spent its energies at St. Louis, and has died out there. But we were not surprised to hear that while the yellow fever was at the Senegal, a virulent smallpox should have broken out among the natives at Bathurst, it having been almost invariably the case that whenever yellow fever made its appearance among the Europeans on that part of the Coast, there should be a great mortality from small-pox among the natives, who do not suffer from yellow fever, as neither do the Europeans from the native small-pox. In a letter from the Gambia which we insert in this present number, it will be seen that the Secretary of State for the Colonies had instructed Sir Samuel Rowe to call at the Gambia on his passage down the West Coast, to inquire into the great neglect and abuses of which we have so often and so vehemently complained. Unfortunately, owing to the pressure of the scare at Cape Coast, Sir Samuel will not have been able to make that visit and inquiry. We are very sorry that this is the case; but, nevertheless, we do venture to hope that the mere fact of such a visit and inquiry having been ordered by the Colonial Office will impel the authorities to make extraordinary efforts to set their house in sanitary order, and that we shall not have again to complain of a state of the burial-ground, the drains, and the general absence of sanitary regulations, such as we have had the painful duty so often to expose and comment upon. The strange neglect by British authorities in almost all the Coast towns of ordinary means to purify the atmosphere is a great disgrace to us as a nation. What has been done at Calcutta, in the East Indies, once as unhealthy a residence for Europeans as any one of the West Coast towns, might long ago have been done in these also. We would ask our readers to glance for a moment at the complaints about the state of Quittah, where a considerable revenue is already raised, and where a much larger one might, it is stated, be raised by a modified scale of Customs' duties, such as would put an end to the temptation of smuggling from the neighbouring sea-coast villages without British jurisdiction. Disgraceful is a word scarcely strong enough to apply to such a state of things. It is a lamentable fact that, so far as the Government is concerned, we do not carry civilization and civilizing efforts with us. Our officers are content to sit upon dung-heaps, surrounded by the most atmospheric-poisoning filth, to collect their Customs' duties; and then we complain of the fatal atmospheric impurities of so many of the sea-coast towns. Is it too much to hope that the new Governor-in-Chief of the Gold Coast Colony will find some remedy for this fearful state of things? As a medical man, we hope that he will prove to be sensitive in this matter. We feel that he has Herculean tasks before him. His predecessors have done so little that there is overwhelming work for him to do, unless he be allowed to appoint subordinates whom he can imbue with his own spirit. We would venture to ask his Excellency's consideration of our Quittah letters. They are brief and plain, but to the point, and, we think, well worthy his attention, so soon as his settlement of the Ashanti episode and the important Lagos question referred to in our last will permit. Our support may not be of much importance, but, such as it is, it will be heartily given to him in every effort to make British rule a mighty civilizing agent and a real blessing to the Gold Coast countries and their people.", 'last_edit_date': '1881-03-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_03_1881#article-16', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.704, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Virulent Small-pox at the Gambia, Quittah Impurities, &c.', 'section_title': '', 'content': "That virulent small-pox should be carrying off daily its ten or a dozen victims from among the small native population of Bathurst, or that any other fatal epidemic should be committing its ravages there, ought not to be a matter of surprise with any one who had read the accounts we have given from time to time, and very recently with added emphasis, of the infamous absence of all adequate sanitary regulations for making the place a safe habitation for human beings, whether white or black. We have, as our readers well know, felt the most serious apprehensions that the yellow fever, which had visited Senegal, would descend to Bathurst, as offering a most tempting field for it to revel in. Happily, however, according to latest advices, it seems to have spent its energies at St. Louis, and has died out there. But we were not surprised to hear that while the yellow fever was at the Senegal, a virulent smallpox should have broken out among the natives at Bathurst, it having been almost invariably the case that whenever yellow fever made its appearance among the Europeans on that part of the Coast, there should be a great mortality from small-pox among the natives, who do not suffer from yellow fever, as neither do the Europeans from the native small-pox. Our support may not be of much importance, but, such as it is, it will be heartily given to him in every effort to make British rule a mighty civilizing agent and a real blessing to the Gold Coast countries and their people.", 'last_edit_date': '1881-03-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_03_1881#article-17', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.726, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Official Delinquencies', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Sir,—About ten months ago small-pox was raging here, and the number of deaths was very large, so the local Government had to appoint an Acting-Assistant Colonial Surgeon to specially look after the small-pox cases, and supervise vaccination. Dr. Taylor, of Sierra Leone, was offered the appointment and accepted it, and fulfilled his duties to the satisfaction of everyone. But a jealous feeling towards that gentleman, on the part of certain of the leading officials, caused an application to be sent to the Colonial Office to send out a doctor from England, and in due time Dr. W. Allan arrived here, and superseded Dr. Taylor, who afterwards left the Colony in disgust. Well, small-pox died away, and Bathurst became healthy; then the Senior Colonial Surgeon, Dr. Spilsbury, went to England on leave of absence, leaving Dr. Allan to perform his duties and look after his private practice (which is a lucrative one) among the European houses. Previous to Dr. Spilsbury going on leave, Captain Roche, the First Writer, or, as he is called here, "the Governor's Secretary," went on leave; and for a time His Excellency managed to do without a "Secretary." But finding this inconvenient, he asked the Chief Clerk at Government House to undertake the duties; and he refused unless he was paid an extra salary—and quite right, too. The Governor then applied to Dr. Allan to take the post, and he accepted it. The consequence is that now his whole day is taken up with his quill-driving duties in the office in Government House, and he has little time to attend to his duties as medical officer; so his patients have to suffer. He tells his patients he has not got time to visit them; that "If he got ten dollars a visit he could not come to them;" that "if he had them all at the Colonial Hospital he might manage to look after them" (i.e., give the dispenser instructions, and leave him to do the best he could), "but he cannot undertake to attend them properly now, as he is the greater part of the day at Government House." Bathurst has been for the past three months rather sickly, particularly among the native folk; and yellow fever, which has decimated the population of St. Louis, Senegal, the deaths being nearly 600, is now bad at Goree; and', 'last_edit_date': '1881-10-25', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_12_1881#article-1', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.71, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'SMALL-POX AT CAPE COAST.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Dear Sir,—Dr. Mosse has responded to the article in the last _African Times_ treating on the introduction of small-pox into this place, and with reference to his reply, there are two matters to which I would particularly draw your attention.

1st. If proper precautions were taken, how came the hospital servant, Quashie Hajan, and a woman and daughter in Gothic House, to catch the disease? The poor woman and daughter died on the same day, a few hours only intervening between the two deaths.

2nd. The small-pox was never introduced here direct from the mail steamers; but was brought by the prisoner from Accra in May last on S.S. Biafra. We shall be glad if Dr. Mosse will refresh our memory as to when, and from what mail steamers this disease was introduced here direct.

Now a few words with reference to the address got up for Mr. Ussher when he was about to leave. You copied into your paper an article from a Cape Coast publication, exposing the state of Cape Coast Town, which was justly said to be one mass of filth—a veritable dung-hill; and you commented upon this in the _African Times_ in a way that stirred up official indignation at him whose article you thus copied in all quarters. To pacify them, he got up an address for Martyr Ussher. He had his own objects in view, of course; but not everybody followed the crafty lead, and I for one refused to sign. You cannot expose in too strong a language that system of addresses of sham praise. Pray continue to do your duty in a straightforward manner, without deference for colour, and God will reward you for your labours.

I hope you will not fail to let the Colonial-office know how, and with what object, that address given to Martyr Ussher was got up to pacify official displeasure.—Yours faithfully,', 'last_edit_date': '1871-11-30', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_01_1872#article-16', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.683, 'probability_score': 0.064, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'EPIDEMIC ON THE AFRICAN COAST', 'section_title': '', 'content': '### EPIDEMIC ON THE AFRICAN COAST.

**February 11.**—Information has been received in Liverpool this morning of a serious outbreak of small-pox at Bathurst, British Gambia, and also that quarantine restrictions are again in force at Goree, Senegal. It is supposed that yellow fever has made its appearance again at the latter place.', 'last_edit_date': '1881-03-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_03_1881#article-4', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.744, 'probability_score': 0.068, 'summary': []}]

hh: The spread of tropical diseases during colonial times in Africa, exacerbated by ecological disruption and movement of people, significantly impacted both European settlers and indigenous populations, leading to widespread mortality, social disruption, and challenges to public health and community life.
result: The observations from the "General History of Africa" textbook and The African Times news articles collectively support the claim that the spread of tropical diseases during colonial times in Africa, exacerbated by ecological disruption and movement of people, significantly impacted both European settlers and indigenous populations. The textbook highlights the prevalence of diseases such as malaria, sleeping sickness, smallpox, and cholera, noting that Europeans were initially more susceptible, with high mortality rates among European soldiers compared to African soldiers. It links ecological disruption from colonial activities, like forest clearance and hunting, to changes in disease environments, particularly in the spread of sleeping sickness. The movement of people, including laborers and displaced communities, facilitated the spread of diseases like malaria and venereal diseases, leading to social disruption, increased witchcraft accusations, and challenges to public health due to inadequate medical infrastructure. Similarly, The African Times articles describe instances of diseases such as African fever, smallpox, and yellow fever affecting both populations, with significant mortality, as seen in the crew of the small barque Mary Anne and Dr. Kirk's report from Zanzibar. The articles also highlight social disruption, such as the abandonment of ivory caravans and impacts on trade, exacerbated by unsanitary conditions in towns like Cape Coast. The movement of infected individuals, like a prisoner from Accra bringing smallpox, further spread diseases. Despite efforts like vaccination campaigns and sanitary measures, public health challenges persisted. Together, these sources illustrate the widespread impact of tropical diseases on European and indigenous populations, leading to mortality and social challenges during colonial times in Africa.
gha: The paragraphs from the "General History of Africa" textbook provide substantial support for the claim that the spread of tropical diseases during colonial times in Africa, exacerbated by ecological disruption and movement of people, significantly impacted both European settlers and indigenous populations. The text highlights the prevalence of diseases such as malaria, sleeping sickness, smallpox, and cholera, which were widespread and often devastating. It notes that Europeans were initially more susceptible to these diseases, with high mortality rates among European soldiers compared to African soldiers. The ecological disruption caused by colonial activities, such as forest clearance and the hunting of game, is linked to changes in disease environments, particularly in the spread of sleeping sickness. The movement of people, including laborers and displaced communities, further facilitated the spread of diseases like malaria and venereal diseases. The text also discusses the social disruption caused by epidemics, including increased witchcraft accusations and social upheavals, as well as the challenges to public health due to inadequate medical infrastructure and resources. Overall, the textbook aligns with the claim by illustrating the significant impact of tropical diseases on both European settlers and indigenous populations, leading to widespread mortality and social challenges.
tat: The African Times news articles provide several details that support the claim regarding the spread of tropical diseases during colonial times in Africa. The articles describe numerous instances of diseases such as African fever, smallpox, and yellow fever affecting both European settlers and indigenous populations, leading to significant mortality. For example, the small barque Mary Anne's crew succumbed to African fever, and Dr. Kirk's letter from Zanzibar reports thousands of deaths due to disease. The articles also highlight the social disruption caused by these diseases, such as the abandonment of ivory caravans and the impact on trade and community life. Additionally, the articles mention the ecological disruption, such as the unsanitary conditions in towns like Cape Coast, which exacerbated the spread of diseases. The movement of people, including the arrival of infected individuals from other regions, further contributed to the spread of diseases, as seen in the case of smallpox brought by a prisoner from Accra. However, the articles also note efforts to combat these diseases, such as vaccination campaigns and sanitary measures, indicating challenges to public health. Overall, the articles align with the claim by illustrating the widespread impact of tropical diseases on both European and indigenous populations during colonial times in Africa.
