Exorbi› tant taxes (increasing in ten years from B.frs 1.25 to B.frs 7) encouraged the population to flee to the Gold Coast instead of raising crops. Forced labour was increased after 1927 by the installation of the administrative services at Niamey and by the extension of the railway. This completely disrupted the farm calendar though the precariousness of the rains made farming times particularly important. The supplies of millet, noncompulsory, depended entirely on the local chiefs. In 1931, the refusal of the administration to lower the head tax, and its insistence on collective payment, which forced the peasants to pay also for deserters and for deceased people, led to a situation in which, as one report put it, 'entire villages vanished ... and an age group was completely decimated'$^{47}$ with, in some areas, a mortality rate of over 50%.", 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.589, 'probability_score': 0.05, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Peoples and states of the Great Lakes region', 'section_title': 'Trading circuits', 'content': 'and Usukuma looked to the Bukerebe surpluses and the Bukerebe marketeers as means of resolution of periodic shortfalls in the local food supply. Occasionally, it seems, this dependence led to accusations against Bukerebe traders of profiteering from the misery of Usukuma farmers by simply raising the prices of Bukerebe food transported to Usukuma during famines. 23 If Bukerebe traders held a predominant middleman position in the south, Basuba intermediaries dominated transport and exchange along the more northerly reaches of this eastern lake trade circuit. With exceptional skill and courage, the Basuba navigated the Lake Victoria waters, trans› porting salt, slaves, dried bananas, grain, beans, livestock, fish, and iron over a great area, connecting the Bukerebe markets in the south to the south Busoga and Buvuma markets in the north. 24 The monopoly of exchange that the Basuba developed over the northern sectors of the eastern lake system in the nineteenth century rather paralleled the monopolies developed by Bagabo and Bashingo traders in the region of the salt lakes in western present-day Uganda.$^{25}$ Each of these groups constructed a well-organized exchange diaspora encompassing political control over production and marketing of salt under the remote licence and protection of the Nyoro and Toro courts. In both the salt lakes and eastern lake circuit, the exchange diaspora evolved its monopoly away from the regular purview of the Lakes Plateau state, did not utilize the model of the state in evolving its marketing network, and only came to accom- modate the demands of states of the region when, occasionally, their regions of production, their markets, and their fleets came under attack.', 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.578, 'probability_score': 0.049, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Peoples and states of the Great Lakes region', 'section_title': 'Coercion, violence and the market', 'content': "Towards the Winam Gulf area, staple foods were frequently in short supply, particularly in the lake littoral zone affected by a unimodal pattern of rainfall and an extended dry season. From at least the eighteenth century, the lakeshore populations moved slowly and steadily upland into the more secure and productive bimodal rainfall areas, constrained only by those groups already occupying the higher ground, by groups over the horizon routinely raiding the rich, higher lands, and by insufficient organization to wedge open more land in the higher zones. This uplands shift in population continues today. It involves transitions in production and diet among those pressing upland, the compression of population in the higher elevations, and the expansion of Luo-speaking communities. The process of upland migration has produced some of the highest rural population densities in Africa in the twentieth century, contributing to the exhaustion of soil and the depletion of forest and woodland reserves. 19 Those who did not migrate upland continued to suffer the shortfalls of a fragile agricultural system. The occasional markets offered some relief, permitting the exchange of cattle, grazed in the lowlands, for grain and root crops grown more successfully at the higher elevations. Since, in the lowlands, the period of hunger was also the period of heaviest labour demand for cultivating and sowing of grains in the first rains, the occasional markets provided a means of overcoming rather quickly the excessively long dry season or an earlier short harvest. Cattle maintained by the people of the lowlands constituted, through regional exchange, the means of agricultural and nutritional continuity. The so-called 'cattle complex' had an immediate logic for the lowland people, providing them with a means of accumulation of convertible wealth.", 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.601, 'probability_score': 0.05, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Peoples and states of the Great Lakes region', 'section_title': 'Coercion, violence and the market', 'content': "If some areas of the Lakes Plateau region were being pushed to increase production far beyond local consumption requirements, other areas experi› enced more than exceptional shortfalls in food production. These shortages were felt both at the beginning of the wet season and during long seasons and years of poor harvests. In western Kenya, occasional markets were opened during periods of crisis.$^{18}$ These were located in the interstices between moister, more secure uplands and drier, less secure lowlands extending in a quarter-circle from the Winam Gulf of western Kenya to southern Busoga. In this area, occasional markets were organized in times of crisis for the exchange of livestock, grain, fish, greens, and manufac› tured goods. Members of the dominant lineage in the area of the market site regulated these exchanges and by the early years of the twentieth century, these market regulators had begun to resemble the 'big men' or 'almost chiefs' familiar to students of different parts of the African continent.", 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.582, 'probability_score': 0.049, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Peoples and states of the Great Lakes region', 'section_title': 'Trading circuits', 'content': 'Fragile agriculture in Rwanda was offset by inter-zonal, inter-ethnic, and inter-class exchange.$^{20}$ Complementarities in production and consumption among regions of surplus and regions of shortfall created a network of communication, exchange, and interaction that reinforced the broader field upon which the Rwandan state was organized. Such routine exchanges may have permitted the retention of specialized local economies, as well as ethnic-specific or class-specific dietary patterns, reinforcing the social class distinctions in the western Lakes Plateau region.', 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.573, 'probability_score': 0.049, 'summary': []}]
tat_orig:
[{'id': 510, 'article_title': 'A Peep through Bathurst and other parts of the River Gambia', 'full_section_title': 'A Peep through Bathurst and other parts of the River Gambia', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_01_1865#article-1', 'issue_date': '23_01_1865', 'content': "In close proximity to the town, towards the left, there was an extensive mangrove swamp, not provided with a natural embankment, and not even by a proper artificial one; consequently, the poorer inhabitants in its neighbourhood were in constant dread of being swamped one fine morning by the overflowing of its banks. I was told that in 1847 and 1851 the rains were so heavy, that the water made its way into the town, a large amount of property was destroyed, and some of the houses were under water. There was a rivulet right through the town; the pedestrians were put to fearful inconvenience and distress; children dare not come out of the houses unless carried. There were few drains, and most of those were in bad condition. There was no proper road to Cape St. Mary's, but a mere footpath, and mostly covered with water. With these partial observations, we retraced our steps towards the beach, and found that our aquatic earth, as the King of Dahomey would call a large steamer, was alongside the jetty of one of the principal merchants. Of course, the swamp so near the town produced the most unhealthy emanations, most prejudicial to European constitutions. But it cannot be said that Bathurst was always in this state of dangerous neglect, because in the time of Governor Randle, in 1838, a capital sea embankment was made with mangrove plants and the trunk of the Talipot Palm. Having now given you a brief account of my first visit to St. Mary's, I shall continue my account of my second visit (1864) in my next, recounting at the same time the improvements which have been made under Colonel d'Arcy's government."}, {'id': 591, 'article_title': 'Report of the Commissioner appointed to Inquire into the Condition of the British Settlements on the West Coast of Africa.', 'full_section_title': 'Report of the Commissioner appointed to Inquire into the Condition of the British Settlements on the West Coast of Africa.', 'last_edit_date': '03-09-1865', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/24_04_1865#article-18', 'issue_date': '24_04_1865', 'content': 'All labour is performed by the domestic slaves of the family, who, as a rule, are kindly treated, and are not often parted with, except under circumstances of necessity.

There is some reason to suppose that coloured traders and trading agents, when following their avocations at a distance from the settlements, occasionally engage in slave-dealing transactions with the natives; but these operations are conducted beyond British jurisdiction, and as yet it has been found impossible to bring any case home to an offender.

In point of unhealthiness the climate of the Gambia probably varies little from that of the other settlements. There is considerable sickness during and after the rains; but many of the merchants, finding that their business makes but light demands upon them during that season, are in the habit of passing in England the worst months of the year. Military officers who suffer in health to any considerable extent are at once invalided, and civil officers are afforded every facility for obtaining the advantages of a change of climate: thus not only are very few Europeans compelled to remain in the colony for any length of time without a change, but there is also a consequent diminution in the number of deaths from the effects of the climate.

It has often been urged that the unhealthiness of the Gambia is largely due to the unfavourable situation of Bathurst, the capital and seat of trade, on the low-lying and swampy Island of St. Mary, and it has been suggested that a great improvement would be effected in this respect by the removal of the seat of government to the more airy and elevated situation of Cape St. Mary.

There can be no question of the superior healthiness of the Cape, and on this account alone the transfer would be very desirable; but

although the government offices might be removed there, it is certain that the merchants would not on this account alone consent to incur the heavy expense of moving their store-houses and long-established places of business from the safe anchorage and convenient landing-places of the river to the exposed situation of St. Mary, which is in no respect so well adapted for the purposes of trade. So long, therefore, as Bathurst remains the seat of trade, it is necessary for its convenience that the custom-house and other public offices connected with it should not be removed from its neighbourhood.

One cause of the unhealthiness of Bathurst is the existence in the immediate neighbourhood of the town of an offensive and pestilent swamp; but from a recent report of Major Clarke, R.E., it appears that, for the sum of about 7,000£, the whole space, covering nearly 1,000 acres, could be closely and efficiently drained. Unfortunately, the circumstances of the colony forbid the hope that it will for a considerable time to come be in a position to afford this outlay, even for a work of such paramount importance to its interests.'}, {'id': 1383, 'article_title': 'Shameful Neglect of the Drains at Bathurst', 'full_section_title': 'Shameful Neglect of the Drains at Bathurst', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_09_1868#article-1', 'issue_date': '23_09_1868', 'content': 'TO THE EDITOR OF THE AFRICAN TIMES.

Bathurst, August 15.

Sir,—Will you kindly call attention again to the state of our treasury and the state of our town—the one running over with money, the other with water and filth? Our people are complaining very much; and well they may. Our Administrator, who has gone off again to England this year, seems to think that levying taxes and getting money into the chest is all that is necessary in Government; he does not think of making any improvements, but only to hoard up money. The balance reported at the end of June quarter was 10,000l., yet our streets are now swampy and unpassable from the constant pouring down of the rain during the last few weeks. One passing in the streets has now to wade in water and mud knee deep, because the drains are utterly neglected, and no labourers employed to clean them out, so as to enable them to carry off the water. It is reported that even the merchants, who seem, under the leading of Mr. Brown, to be now our implacable enemies and oppressors, have written a complaint to the Administrator, as they fear that, if the drainage is not immediately attended to, some dreadful sickness will soon come down upon all the inhabitants, white as well as black.—Yours, &c.,'}, {'id': 2361, 'article_title': 'WHEAT CULTIVATION IN WEST AFRICA', 'full_section_title': 'WHEAT CULTIVATION IN WEST AFRICA', 'last_edit_date': '12-08-1872', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/30_01_1873#article-2', 'issue_date': '30_01_1873', 'content': 'My Dear Sir,—Enclosure No. 1 was ready for the post on Tuesday last, when an outward steamer arrived, bringing me your last, of the 11th ult., and I did not therefore post it, as your last informs me that Lord Granville’s kind interest in the wheat question had been successful, and the seeds sure to be in your hands in a day or two.

Thinking, however, that the enclosure may interest you, as showing the estimation in which the question is held among our neighbours here, I now send it on. I also put in another letter—Enclosure No. 2—addressed to me on the 15th ult., bearing on the same subject. The writer of this is an enterprising young native trader, residing at Berracoe, near Winiba. Berracoe is one of the lately ceded Dutch settlements, and the port of a fine fertile tract of country which was the seat of the Aquamboe power in the time of the old Dutch writer (historian) Bosman, ere they (the Aquamboes) were driven beyond the Volta by the combined forces of Accra, Aquapim, and Western Akim. You will find a sketch of the past history of that particular part of

* The drains in the back part of the town are badly wrought out, inasmuch as wherever there is the least shower of rain, most part of the town is inundated for days together, especially that part called the Old Race-course, where people unavoidably must go across in attending to their daily callings. The market women suffer mostly in going across this way to the market, when they must have to wade knee-deep about one hundred yards across. The streets are also very uneven, principally those in the back part of the town; in some of them there is no drain, and in others there are drains only seven or eight inches deep, which, in such a loose sandy place as Bathurst, are liable to inundation by the very first shower of rain after they are dug for one to pass through the footpath, rendering it very inconvenient for the people and your petitioners generally. All along the west end of the town of Bathurst, being subject to all filth,—rubbish, broken bottles, and dead animals unburied, exposed to the air and sun,—contributed more to the unhealthiness of the inhabitants and of the petitioners generally.

---

the Gold Coast in my chapter on the Aquamboes in my MS. now in your hands for publication.

I am glad you are having an eye to an additional supply of seeds from the new supply of seeds from the new crop; and you may rely, all being well, on my keeping you duly informed on the progress of culture as soon as we get fairly to work.

I will answer your inquiry about the tramway proposition by an early opportunity. Hoping this will find you well, I am, dear Sir, yours ever sincerely,'}, {'id': 3711, 'article_title': 'OFFICIAL CORRESPONDENCE.', 'full_section_title': 'OFFICIAL CORRESPONDENCE.', 'last_edit_date': '01-12-1879', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_02_1879#article-4', 'issue_date': '01_02_1879', 'content': 'Sir,—The afflicting news brought this day by the S.S. Lunlaha of the mortality from fever at the Gambia, calls anew for the application of preventive measures which ought to have been long since adopted in a place which has been so often decimated by disease engendered in the pestilential swamps, to hope that Her Majesty's Government will order the effective drainage of which would be further to encourage a fatal delusion.

One of my trustworthy correspondents at Bathurst thus writes:—

"The angel of death has been with us—paid us a long visit—exacted a heavy tribute of victims, and left his mark indelibly stamped on this unfortunate town.

"Mr. Carr, the Chief Magistrate, four Europeans, and three natives were swept off in one day.

"It is a fearful sight to walk through Bathurst; nearly every one is in mourning, even the poorest of the natives. Death has touched all.

"There is a large surplus—several thousand pounds—in the treasury."

There seems every reason to believe that a liberal planting of Eucalyptus globulosa trees would, within a very few years, effect much of what is needed for health, and convert the fatal climate of Bathurst into a salubrious one.

The French Government are said to have planted above 2,000,000 Eucalyptus globulosa trees in the malarious swampy districts of Algeria, and the results are reported to have been most satisfactory.

Under these distressing circumstances, I take the liberty to call upon Her Majesty's Government, in the name and on the part of the suffering residents at Bathurst, both native and European, to order and direct that, in addition to those engineering measures which the local authorities have most shamefully neglected, sufficient planting of Eucalyptus globulosa trees in and about these poisonous swamps, so fatal to the public health, should be immediately ordered and effected.—I have the honour to remain, Sir, yours respectfully,  
F. FITZGERALD, Editor of the _African Times_.

To Sir Michael Hicks-Beach, M.P.,  
H.M. Principal Secretary of State for the Colonies.'}, {'id': 3974, 'article_title': 'A Memorial of the Natives of Bathurst Asking the Remedy of Serious Evils', 'full_section_title': 'A Memorial of the Natives of Bathurst Asking the Remedy of Serious Evils', 'last_edit_date': '03-28-1879', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_06_1880#article-2', 'issue_date': '01_06_1880', 'content': "To His Excellency Samuel Rowe, C.M.G., Governor-in-Chief of the West African Settlements, &c.

The Memorial of the undersigned native inhabitants of Bathurst respectfully showeth—

1. That your Excellency's memorialists having observed with regret the state of things in Bathurst, humbly crave leave to submit their views to your Excellency, with a request that they should receive your Excellency's consideration.

2. For the past few years a system has been introduced to this Settlement of utilizing convict labour in cases where the labour of mechanics and other artisans is absolutely required. The effect of such an anomalous procedure has been to discourage native industry, and to hamper all exertions tending to the development of their capacities.

3. Your Excellency's memorialists would not be understood to question the right of the government to convict labour in so far as it is available without detriment to the prosperity of the community; they would, however, submit that the practice of apportioning public works amongst convicts and policemen to the utter exclusion of artisans of competent skill in the place is not only displeasing, but is calculated to produce bad work in the Settlement, although money is economically expended on their construction.
**63**

4. As one of the results of this niggardly policy may be instanced the condition of the streets in the rains, when it would be expected that active steps would be taken by the authorities to prevent their being overflowed with water. The drains, already overgrown with weeds, simply through neglect, conduce not a little to the impediments offered to peregrinators, by means of which they are obliged to wade knee-deep in the mud to get to their destinations. Convicts, like any one else without the necessary qualification to perform works of public importance, may be of use in patching up the streets with loose earth to be washed away in the rainy season; whereas if a few more pounds are granted to expend on really competent persons to have the drains properly kept, and the streets macadamized, not only the subsidiary, but the main object of Government would be attained.

5. In former years an impetus was given to the natives, most of whom then fondly believed that encouragement would be continued to them in whatever branch of industry they embarked themselves. The course of action initiated by your Excellency's predecessor in office, has checked your Excellency's memorialists from indulging in these fanciful chimeras. They would, nevertheless, point out a few drawbacks and grievances to their advancement, which it is in your Excellency's power to remedy."}, {'id': 6031, 'article_title': 'THE GAMBIA', 'full_section_title': 'THE GAMBIA', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/07_11_1890#article-7', 'issue_date': '07_11_1890', 'content': "The latest accounts from this settlement are not too cheerful, the Administrator and the colonial surgeon being the only European officials fit for duty. The colonial engineer died on Oct. 1 from a severe attack of malarial fever, after a residence of only three months in the colony. On Sept. 22 he accompanied the Administrator to Albreda, and while there the best accommodation was afforded by a house belonging to a French merchant which is built on a swampy and unwholesome site, the dangerous character of which was increased by torrents of rain which fell the day after their arrival.

The steam yacht which conveyed the Administrator to Albreda proceeded to M'Carthy's Island, 100 miles further up the river, and it was his Excellency's intention to return to Bathurst by her when she was able to fulfil her mission, but owing to a strong current caused by the heavy rains she was delayed much beyond the time expected. In the meantime the colonial engineer had contracted fever, and the Administrator decided to proceed to Bathurst in an open boat, a distance of 16 miles, so that medical advice might be obtained. A start was accordingly made on Sept. 26, and Bathurst was safely reached. Here Mr. Hingeston received immediate attention, but, in spite of every remedy, he succumbed to syncope. At the same time Lieut.-Colonel Tighe, the superintendent of police, was lying seriously ill of a like complaint, in a portion of the quarters occupied by the colonial engineer, and to save the shock, which in all probability would have killed him, he was removed to Government House, and the news of his comrade's death kept from him as long as possible. Colonel Tighe rallied from the attack, but he has been invalided to England, as it was thought improbable that he would thoroughly regain his health without a radical change.

There can be no doubt that the town of Bathurst during a heavy rainy season is one of the most unhealthy places in the world. St. Mary's Island, on which the town is built, is a perfectly flat sand bank with a considerable admixture in the soil of the ooze of the great river Gambia. It is well-nigh impossible to drain it, although attempts have been made. Certain it is that many of the drains do not act, and without great expense no effective system of drainage could be accomplished.

Unfortunately the deep water is on the St. Mary's side of the channel, otherwise the town would be far more healthily situated on the mainland at Borra Point.

The rainfall up to last report has been 59 in., as compared with 32 in. in 1889 for the whole year."}]
tat_extra:
[{'document_title': 'Death of the Acting Administrator at the Gambia, and Alleged Incompetency of the Colonial Engineer', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Captain H. T. A. Cooper, late Acting Administrator at the Gambia died at 11.15 a.m. on the 9th of January, and was interred on the morning of the 10th. Great complaint is made to us from Bathurst, that the Colonial Engineer is not at all up to his work—some of which, at the Colonial Church, Governor Rome is stated to have ordered to be stopped. There is serious complaint, also, as to his work on the drains—a very important matter in Bathurst; and even in the affair of the burial of the late Administrator, he is accused of having had a coffin made so small that the body had to be forced into it, and a brick grave so constructed that it gave way when the body was to be lowered, so that a new one had to be made, and it was nearly noon before the interment could be completed. We do not know anything of Mr. J. C. Bauer, the Engineer in question, and shall be very sorry indeed if we have been misled by the above account; but we have a distinct recollection that great evils were said to have been caused some years ago, and much mortality occasioned, by the Colonial Engineer of that period having mismanaged the drainage of Bathurst; and with this in our mind, it has appeared to be strictly our duty to bring the alleged inefficiency of the actual Engineer at the Gambia to the knowledge of those whom it officially concerns, in order that due inquiry may be made. The public health in Bathurst is so intimately connected with efficient drainage, that it was impossible for us to avoid publicly noticing the communication made to us.', 'last_edit_date': '1877-03-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_03_1877#article-3', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.664, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'A Memorial of the Natives of Bathurst Asking the Remedy of Serious Evils', 'section_title': '', 'content': "6. The cemetery of Bathurst requires attention. During the spring tide of last year, the local government felt itself compelled, perhaps for its own safety, to proclaim that those of your Excellency's memorialists whose relations' coffins were exhumed by water should look after their dead, no precaution whatever having been taken to preserve the remains of those for whose memory your Excellency's memorialists cherish the highest respect in God's acre. A mock attempt to keep away the water by Mr. Bauer, the engineer, whose signal failure your Excellency's memorialists are willing to attribute to the parsimony of the government, which endeavoured to make use of mangrove and empty barrels to stop the sea encroachments, instead of erecting substantial dykes, or embankments for the purpose. The safety of the people could hardly have been in contemplation of the government, or steps in the right direction might have been taken to bring about this desirable end.

7. Gutters are urgently needed at Half Die. The streets in that part of the town are literally overflowed with water, on the subsidence of which a very sickening smell is produced by the filth generated by fecal matters, whose decomposition is accelerated by stagnant waters. The construction of sewers would drain off those offensive matters, and render the atmosphere pure and wholesome.

8. Dry earth closets are in great demand in this settlement. The expense of erecting these is trifling when compared with the beneficial results that would flow from them. Strangers visiting these shores very often find themselves obliged to attend to the calls of nature, in places where a sense of decency should deter them from using. The reason for this is to be found in the want of public closets. Regret is often expressed at the unhealthiness of Bathurst, which is to a great extent enhanced by the filthy habits of Mandingoes, and other aboriginal tribes who come to Bathurst for trading purposes. The erection of these closets, in various parts of the town, would lessen the unhealthiness produced by the stench emanating from the excrements and nuisances of the tribes alluded to. *Your Excellency's memorialists humbly solicit that an ordinance be passed declaring it unlawful for Jolahs, Sereres, and others to walk the streets stark naked.*

9. In connection with the matter lastly herein above alluded to, may be mentioned the desirability of appointing a sanitary inspector or water police, whose duty should be to prevent the sick that are brought from the rivers, and foreign places, being thrown on the wharves to take care of themselves, or die. The establishment of a water police force, apart from effecting the object herein mentioned, would restrain dishonest persons from infringing the revenue laws of this Settlement, and from making clandestine removal of goods at night.", 'last_edit_date': '1879-03-28', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_06_1880#article-2', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.694, 'probability_score': 0.068, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'THE FEVER AT BATHURST', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Weeping and mourning are at the Gambia; desolation and woe have fallen upon the unhappy town of Bathurst. A pestilential fever, against the threatened approaches of which no efforts at prevention were made by ignorant, incapable, and criminally erring officials, marched up from the foetid swamp, descended into the habitations of rich and poor, European and native; and death, terror, and dismay reigned supreme over all. The graphic letter on our 2nd page tells a little of the fatal tale. The Chief Magistrate, a young man in the full vigour and strength of life, four Europeans, and three natives, fell victims in one day. Well might the poor stricken people believe that this was only the vanguard of the Yellow Fever which had made its ravages at Senegal; and against the probable coming of which we had warned the besotted officials, who were too intent, each on his own little game, to heed our earnest entreaties to set their house in order. A heavy responsibility for the precious lives that have been taken away, should lie at the door of those whose duty it was to take adequate measures for the preservation of the public health. The large surplus which is the present boast of the Gambia Treasury—to create which the public service has in many ways been starved, and for creating which personal promotion is no doubt expected—is now made loathsome by the putrid corpses of victims whose lives have been sacrificed to it. Cynics and profound moralists equally affirm, that at the present time nothing is worshipped but money. The officials of Gambia and Sierra Leone may be adduced in support of the truth of this stigma. We earnestly hope the results will not be as fatal in the latter place as in the former. But when blundering, incapacity, and selfishness had done their worst, a kind Providence stepped in with its healthy Harmattan wind, and the pestilence gradually abated. We hope the influence of that health-giving wind will be felt at other parts of the Coast. Its absence last year was deeply deplored at Lagos, where small-pox and other fatal diseases then prevailed. But although the pestilence has been killed for a time at Bathurst by the Harmattan, we hope the present safety will not renew the guilty official apathy; and that the lives of the inhabitants will be deemed of more value than a few hundreds of pounds, more or less, in the Treasury. We say advisedly, guilty official apathy. Look at paragraphs in a letter from Bathurst in our last month's paper, page 2: "The streets and drains are very dirty, the effluvia from the latter very bad; the native yards in a filthy state; and though we pay local rates of 400l. a year, and there is a surplus now in the Treasury of 6,000l., yet not a penny can or will be spared for sanitary measures, because Mr. Bauer" (the Colonial Engineer) "will not act;" and yet we are face to face with a most sickly season; fever fast approaching to an epidemic in virulence; deaths are rapid and numerous, natives as well as Europeans. Still nothing is done!" Our correspondent goes on to say that some months ago, "We sent a petition to the Colonial Secretary, complaining of the inefficiency of the Engineer Department, asked for a Board of Inquiry, and engaged to substantiate all our charges. Dr. Gouldsbury" (the Administrator, who is a most intimate friend of Mr. Bauer and his family) "wrote to Sir Michael Hicks-Beach, to the effect that our statements were false; our complaints personal feeling; that Mr. Bauer was a 'most zealous and efficient officer,' &c. The Colonial Secretary wrote back to us to the effect that, in view of the Governor's report, he gave no credence to our statements, and would not grant any inquiry." In other words, the memorialists of Bathurst had the lie given to them, in the same way that it was also given to those of Sierra Leone; in both cases upon the mere ipse dixit of the erring Governor. Alas! what a commentary on all this is the fearful mortality that has plunged Bathurst into wailing, lamentation, and woe; a mortality distinctly traceable to Engineering and Administrative favouritism and incapacity or heartless indifference. Do not these events furnish a startling proof of the necessity of combined action on the West Coast, that all the settlements and populations, European merchants as well as natives, should have our constant help to bring their wants and just complaints in such a way before Her Majesty's Government, that it shall not be in the power of erring officials, however high their grade, to call down Imperial insult on an injured people; and obstruct the course of reforms on which the lives of the inhabitants and the prosperity of the Settlement depend?', 'last_edit_date': '1879-02-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_02_1879#article-14', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.662, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Cholera at Bathurst—Fearful Ravages', 'section_title': '', 'content': "It is with deep emotion that we have read the accounts sent to us by the bi-monthly mail from the River Gambia. The cholera, which at the date of our previous advices seemed to have relaxed a little in its severity, had broken out again with augmented vigour, and the deaths at Bathurst were on the average of 60 to 70 to 90 a-day. Out of the small population of Bathurst no less than 1,100 had already fallen victims to this fearful malady, which the African constitution, unaided, seems to have no power to resist. In the majority of cases death ensues within five or six hours. There seems to be one universal voice of condemnation as regards the official conduct of the Administrator. If ever there was an occasion when public revenue derived from Customs' duties (as they are here) ought to be unsparingly applied to arrest the progress of disease and alleviate the sufferings of a people, surely this was one; but although we see by the estimates that this small colony can afford, or is made to afford, nearly 10,000l. a year in official salaries, the Administrator, if he has not entirely sealed up the colonial chest against the demands of suffering humanity, has at least only allowed assistance in such driblets, and in so inefficient a manner, that no small share of the frightful mortality is charged openly against him by all classes of persons in the colony, from the European merchant down to the meanest native. Experience everywhere, as Admiral Patey must have well known, has established the efficacy of preventive measures in arresting the course of Asiatic cholera, provided those measures are of the right kind, and are vigorously and unsparingly applied; but little or nothing, so far as we can learn, seems to have been done by him to prevent the invasion and spread of this disease at Bathurst. The culpable parsimony and inefficiency of one man have thus brought disease and a horrible death into the homes of hundreds. Hitherto we do not hear that any European has died in Bathurst of this fell disease, but many were suffering under premonitory symptoms. The medical men in the colony (Dr. Jeans and Waters) seem to be doing their duty; we were prepared to expect this by their straightforward conduct in the Gordon case, which has no doubt brought down upon them the official ire. Dr. J. Africanus Horton, S.A.S., has, we hear from Cape Coast, been ordered up to Bathurst, and we know that he will not be found wanting in humanity or zeal. His eminent services in the Grobobo Expedition and Ashantee War, which never received any reward, are a guarantee of this.", 'last_edit_date': '1869-06-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_06_1869#article-22', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.675, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Bathurst Complaints', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'We are indeed pained to learn, from the Memorial addressed by some of the native inhabitants of Bathurst to the Governor-General at Sierra Leone, that the injudicious and dangerous economy and neglect which we have in other years exposed continues at this town on the Gambia. This indifference and neglect, which we feel justified in designating criminal, not only interferes with the progress of civilization, but subjects the community, both European and native, to renewed outbreaks of those destroying pestilences which have from time to time decimated the town of Bathurst. Year after year the educated native inhabitants, as well as Europeans, have protested against the continued permission by the authorities to the natives from the river villages who flock to Bathurst for trade, to perambulate the town in a state of nudity, and perform all the operations of nature when and where they choose, without the slightest regard to decency, and in defiance of all sanitary regulations which ought to be enforced in any town under British rule and law. We are at a loss to understand why such things should be—why British officials should continue to tolerate them, as if a decree had gone forth that it was not desirable that the blessings of civilization should extend in Africa. Bathurst, and all other towns on the Coast under British government, ought to be brought fully under civilized regulations, and become spots from which civilization should radiate into the neighbouring territories. That they should not be this, is a gross neglect of duty on the part of the authorities, and reflects deep disgrace on Great Britain. It is absurd to suppose that there could be any real difficulty in insisting upon public decency within the town of Bathurst. While the unclothed natives from the river villages are allowed to come into the town in their unclothed condition, and treat the town in every way as if it were the bush or fields in which they reside, they will no doubt continue to do so, and look with ignorant and barbarous contempt upon the inhabitants who are not permitted, and would no longer permit themselves, the offensive freedom from all self-restraint which they, the "untutored savages," enjoy. Is it too much to expect that British authority will now at last interfere on the side of decency and health? The "untutored savage" would not forego the substantial benefits he or she derives from his or her visits to Bathurst because compelled to wear a proper cloth and conform to certain sanitary regulations; and, accustomed to these self-restraints within the town of Bathurst, they will thus have entered, however superficially, into the arena of civilization, and become more accessible to the propaganda of civilization among themselves. Important, however, as this change for which we call would really prove to be, it is but secondary when viewed in connection with that continued neglect of the drains, and that continuous horrible condition of the place of sepulture, respecting which the Memorialists protest. Everyone who has watched and recorded the ravages of epidemics on the West Coast of Africa must remember but too well the awful visitations to which Bathurst has been subject. Only last year it was threatened with one of them, and not a few persons perished from its advancing breath, when, happily, a sudden meteorological change drove back the fearful enemy. In some of our letters we find fears expressed that the present season may be rather an unhealthy one on the West Coast, and the mere suspicion that it will be so ought to induce precaution on the part of individuals and authorities. The latter are to a certain extent answerable for the lives of the population over whom they rule; they are fully answerable to the extent of removable causes; and among removable causes, that of pestilential drains, of filthy thoroughfares, and of graveyards in which the decaying dead are exposed to public view, filling the atmosphere with poisonous gases, must certainly be included. By the time this number of our journal reaches Bathurst the fiend of pestilence may—though we fervently pray it will not—may, we say, be upon the town. Should such, unhappily, be the case—should there be a new holocaust of victims offered up on the shrine of official incompetency, indifference, or neglect,—we shall cry loudly for retribution on those who shall have thus trifled with the lives of a community, to protect and defend which is one of the most sacred of the duties with which they are charged.', 'last_edit_date': '1880-06-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_06_1880#article-14', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.694, 'probability_score': 0.068, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'THE CONDITION OF THE GAMBIA.', 'section_title': '', 'content': '5. Although rates are regularly levied for the purpose of repairing drains and making other local improvements in Bathurst, and the attention of the Administration has been repeatedly directed to this subject, yet the sanitation of the town is in a most neglected condition, and Half Die and Newtown, the most unhealthy localities, left to take care of themselves. In the rainy season, the town is generally inundated from want of responsible persons to take care of the Sluice Gates, causing great loss and damage to property. The Colonial Engineer, whom the Colony pays £550 a year, is always on leave during the rains, when his presence is most needed to study the condition of the place.

6. An Ordinance to repeal the Trade License Ordinance, 1893, and to make other provisions in lieu thereof, was passed at the Legislative Council held on the 18th ult. The provisions of the Ordinance in question are one-sided, and, above all, unconstitutional. The Colony is dependent for its prosperity on the trade carried on in the Rivers. Local taxes as such cannot bring a Revenue, and when the Administration under the pretext of protecting the large mercantile houses, which are well able to take care of themselves, from being defrauded by their traders, restricts liberty of commerce in the rivers and renders it possible for licenses to be arbitrarily refused to applicants for the same, it deals a fatal blow to the prosperity of the Colony whose resources, as it is well known, are very limited. Section 4 of the Ordinance reads as follows:—

"That it shall be lawful for the Colonial Treasurer or any such Commissioner to refuse to issue a license to any applicant, unless such applicant shall first produce a certificate signed by a member of either the Executive or Legislative Council and by two Justices of the Peace that he is of good character and a fit and proper person to be entrusted with such license."

The chief objection to this section is that it is unconstitutional, and interferes arbitrarily with the liberties of a British subject. It also opens a wide field for abuse, and practically places the liberties of the entire trading community in the hands of three unofficial members of the Executive or Legislative Council who are themselves merchants. All men are human, business men not excepted; and would it not be a source of temptation for men wielding such a power to place obstacles in the way of their fellow competitors, the other mercantile firms and small business houses? The section providing for the revocation of licenses is also impolitic. It follows that all traders who cannot obtain a license, or whose licenses may be revoked, will be obliged to flock at Bathurst to become a source of danger to the community, as all unemployed necessarily are under the pressure of want and distress.', 'last_edit_date': '1895-08-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_10_1895#article-1', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.658, 'probability_score': 0.065, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Pestilential Swamps at Bathurst—Remedy', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Sir,—The interest which you take in the agricultural progress of Her Majesty’s settlements on the West Coast of Africa induces me to trouble you with the result of experiments made with the sunflower.

Bathurst, January 7, 1868.

Memorandum of the weights of different kinds of sunflower seed cultivated by myself—viz.:

- Macrophyllus gigantea, single large flower 25lbs. 29lbs.
- Helianthus, or common sunflower—black seed bushel. bushel.
- Mixed, but mostly white and grey: 36lbs. 41lbs.
- 37lbs. 43lbs.

The above seed was grown at Bathurst, partly in a garden that had been manured, and partly in the Government paddock, a sandy patch opposite the sea, and full of weeds.

Common sunflower, mixed, black, white, and grey seed, grown in the Upper River, above McCarthy’s Island—a first experiment as a field crop there:—

- Striked bushel. Heaped bushel.
- 29½lbs. 34lbs.

Experiments have been made in Italy to arrest the deadly effects arising from the miasma of the marshes and swamps in some parts of that country, by planting a belt of sunflowers on the edges of the swamps, which form a wall, and thus check the progress of the noxious gases evolved; it being a well-known fact that miasma never rises above a certain height. Here, then, lies the possible remedy or check to the dreadful fever from which the Gambia suffers, and which mostly prevail during the rainy season, when the wind usually blows from W. to S.W. over the swamps at the back of the town of Bathurst, wafting their deadly influence into our midst.

Unless this can be prevented, all the attention that could possibly be paid to the state of the town drains would be of little avail. We must strike at the root of the evil, and while doing so in the manner suggested—for a system of perfect drainage of these pestilent swamps would be attended with an enormous outlay at the beginning, and a never-ending expense for keeping it in repair, owing to the sandy nature of the soil, and the island being in many places below the level of the sea, with very doubtful results—the yield of sunflower seed would prove a valuable return for the annual expense of planting. There are, however, other plants and trees that could be made available, and permanently so, to accomplish the object in view.—I am, Sir, your obedient servant,

H. Melton,  
Introducer of the Cotton-seed into England in 1847; and Inventor, in 1853, of the method of Wood-sheathing, and afterwards Coppering, Iron Ships.

GAMBIA.', 'last_edit_date': '1873-01-05', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/30_01_1873#article-0', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.651, 'probability_score': 0.065, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'A Peep through Bathurst, River Gambia', 'section_title': '', 'content': "In my last account I brought your readers' notice to the condition of the colony on my first visit, in 1865. I made another trip in July, 1864, during a season which all ground-nut traders called good, as the rains were plentiful, and there was every prospect of a good crop. I was surprised to see large and well-regulated drains made or making in almost every part where I went, walled on either side with stone or bricks—running from one side of the town to the other, and emptying into the sea. A great many were in an imperfect state, some of which were interrupted by the approach of the rainy season.

It was pleasant to see fine squares in the middle of the town, all covered with the green Bahama grass, and some of the drains supplied with railings. It struck me at once that there was a wonderful change in the interior of Bathurst since I last had seen it. There were good bridges in the centres of the streets, where in 1855 I had to walk knee deep in water. There was no more an inundation from the muddy swamp at the back and left of the town, a proper sea embankment having been made by the present Governor, which led to the securing of a large tract of land from the water. This land has been a great source of revenue to the Colonial Government, as it was afterwards divided into lots, and sold at a very advantageous rate, bringing over 600l. to the colonial coffers. The road to the burial-ground, which was in a fearful state of swamp, and in many parts covered over with water, is now converted into a hard road, and forms a pleasurable walk.

At this visit I rode to the cape. It is a distance of about seven miles. The road from St. Mary's to the ferry was excellent and hard—a good carriage drive. The boat employed in the ferry is an antiquated piece of workmanship, perhaps about fifty or a hundred years old, of an American origin, equally broad in stern and bow, and worked by paddles manned by four men. Sometimes the boat is drifted about 300 yards beyond its landing-place. I have never seen such an ugly piece of mechanism, and it is tiresome to see the poor men labouring to make this huge log move; and although it is said that the colony is in a state of bankruptcy, I hope they will soon be able to replace it with something more modern and workable. The road from the ferry to the cape is partly good and partly bad, the latter portion being rapidly repairing by the civilian prisoners. The material used by the Governor is the shell of the common cockle, mixed with those of other gregarious mollusks.

All along the road are large Bombax, or monkey bread trees, and I noticed hollows scraped out of a great many of them; and on inquiry I was told that they were so ordered to be done by the Governor, to form rests for the women who carry loads on their heads.", 'last_edit_date': '1865-05-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_05_1865#article-15', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.692, 'probability_score': 0.068, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Horrible and Dangerous State of Cape Coast after Forty Years of British Rule', 'section_title': '', 'content': "We have already endeavoured to direct the notice of the authorities to the abominable condition of the streets, lanes, and gutters of this town. We have no desire to trump up grievances, nor is it our wish to be for ever harping upon the same theme. But, in the interests of the entire public, we must again entreat those who have power to make some effort towards compelling people to deposit their dirt in some other places than the public thoroughfares. There is not the slightest exaggeration in saying that, for some time past, the town of Cape Coast, the head-quarters of Her Majesty's forts and settlements on the Gold Coast, has been one vast dunghill! We are all being actually poisoned by the foul atmosphere we breathe. A few days ago we tried to walk on the Anamaboe-road, but found it impossible to do so with safety to health; for upon that road, and within the precincts of this town, it would have been necessary to wade through thirty yards of sheer dung and minor garbage. An attempt has since been made to clean a part of this horrible and deadly accumulation, but not much good has been done. In various places in the very centre of Cape Coast, large masses of the most offensive matter render it really dangerous to pass by.

The health of the town is very bad in consequence of all this, and it is the opinion of experienced persons that we shall have some fatal pestilence before September.

We have written this article at the earnest request of several most respectable persons, native and European; and we have reason to hope that this appeal to his Excellency the Administrator will not have been made in vain.", 'last_edit_date': '1871-04-24', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/24_04_1871#article-8', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.656, 'probability_score': 0.065, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'SIERRA LEONE.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The sanitary condition of the settlement is said to be at present very unsatisfactory, owing to necessary work not being executed; "economy at all risks" being the Government order of the day. The starving of "education" and "sanitary works" is very likely to induce "moral" and "physical" pestilence, which will more than counterbalance any pecuniary advantages that may be obtained by an unwise administrative economy.', 'last_edit_date': '1878-09-02', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_09_1878#article-4', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.648, 'probability_score': 0.065, 'summary': []}]
